column1: Will there be a lethal confrontation between the national military forces, militia, and/or law enforcement personnel of India and the People's Republic of China before 1 January 2023?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict', 'Non-US Politics']
Why there will:
Just a few days are left.
Time decay
Cost of war is too high
What am I missing? There was already a quite ugly DUST UP between these two just weeks ago! Why is this still up?

If you look at the Economist, they are reporting Chinese "incursions" inside of India territory including tent placement, punch ups. But there is just a week left before the end date of this problem and this analyst doesn't see the lethal confrontation happening, unless of course it is an accident.
Lower on “minor” injuries reported, but not going back to single digits. There’s no love lost and things can flare up with little warning.
Serious 'dust up' in the past few days...

Under current conditions it is almost certain that a lethal clash will not happen. Border guards are not armed with firearms, so a lethal clash would require parties to come within maybe 20 meters of each other and then engage in an altercation using improvised weapons or thrown objects.
China has enough going on without risking this kind of escalation. Using a foreign enemy as a rallying point or distraction for domestic problems could be useful but the timing is not ideal globally.
It's too cold for fighting now.
Borrowing my previous notes from my answer for this question extended to 1 January 2024.
Winter has almost arrived and cold affects everything including confrontation potential

Oct 26 article in the Daily Pioneer: "As troops from both the sides have disengaged from the last stand-off site in Ladakh, External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar on Wednesday said normalisation of ties between India and China is in the interest of everyone, including the world at large." https://www.dailypioneer.com/2022/india/normalisation-of-ties-between-india-and-china-in-global-interest--jaishankar.html Modi & Xi will attend the G-20 in mid-Nov. Should note what statements emerge if they have a bilateral meeting.
Passage of time

Tensions may be high yet these two have key relationships, part of the BRICS alliance, and india imports so much from china and exports a big amount of gold there too. China is also more focused on taiwan and india with pakistan.

Further reducing given talks between India and China before the Party Congress in China: https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/india-china-hold-consultations-ahead-of-important-communist-party-congress-in-beijing/article66002339.ece
The unified foreign policy approach to Russia by India and China, albeit for similar and differing reasons, reduces belligerent interactions between the two states. This event remains unlikely.
1. Season - most parts are not accessible. Napoleon/Hitler experienced this with the Russian winter. We are talking substantially colder/harsher climate/geographic conditions

My assessment of the likelihood of a violent clash between the PRC and India before JAN 2023 remains low. The 16th round of high-level mil to mil talks has resulted in both parties "pulling back" forces from certain points along the frontier. This is largely symbolic but represents a commitment at the highest levels of military leadership to de-escalate the situation.
CCP congress and weather

Context: Both India and China have military forces at the disputed border in the Himalaya. There were various reasons cited, including Indian construction activity, Chinese encroachment ("salami slicing"), shifting power balances, need for a show of force during the COVID-19 pandemic in China, but no concrete immediate cause except shots fired on 7 September 2020 for which both sides accuse each other.
Party congress and ev. new government in China.
-Calculated base rate from January 2020 until now. 3% is what I found on a per month chance, with only one month containing multiple deaths due to an incident.
Not sure it makes sense during 20th party Congress and transition to new government.

If this were to happen, I imagine it would be an accident stumble into conflict rather than a conscious, deliberate attack by either side. Does not seem to be in either party's interest at the moment.

This week I revisited my original forecast for the likelihood of a fatal border clash between Indian and Chinese forces. I decided to approach my base rate differently. Instead of calculating a monthly rate based on the recent clashes since 2020 (18%), I calculated the annual likelihood of the lethal clash since Indian independence (5%). However, we have only have a few more months left in the years, so I scaled my base rate down to a modest 1.5%. Working from this much lower base rate, I took into account many of the same factors I did with my original prediction, as well as some new ones: ongoing but inconclusive talks (-5%), publicly commitments to not give up ground (+5%), Indian involvement in the quad (+5%), and a 1993 treaty preventing border patrols from being armed (-5%). Ultimately, I rounded up to a 2% overall chance of a lethal clash.

Sept 9 article in the South China Morning Post: "Tensions are easing between China and India as their troops pull back from the Gogra-Hotsprings frontier in the western Himalayas ... China’s defence ministry on Friday said both sides had begun disengaging on Thursday." https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3191996/tensions-ease-china-india-border-amid-changing-geopolitical

Will there be a lethal confrontation between the national military forces, militia and/or law enforcement personnel of India and the PRC between 1 JAN 2023? I forecast that there is an 18% chance that a lethal clash will occur during this time frame. I established a base rate of 41.67% based on the annual rate of clashes during the 12 month period from May 2020 to May 2021. Of these past clashes, only one in five resulted in fatalities. This caused me to put the likelihood of a fatal clash at 8.33%, assuming the same level of tensions as persisted between 2020 and 2021. Talks are ongoing but have been inconclusive (-5%). India's defense minister has publicly committed to not give up ground (+5%). India also remains committed tot he Quad and has taken part in combined exercises with Quad members (+10%).

This shouldn't be at 8% (current crowd score) anymore in my opinion. First, there is the deescalation news posted by @StringerBell Secondly, the India-China border region is experiencing rapidly declining temperatures as summer turns to fall, so renewed hostilities are less likely when the weather is cold.
Deescalation: https://www.nytimes.com/2022/09/09/world/asia/india-china-border.html
Has happened recently - small scale though, not full war.
1. Too much to lose.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TKXldNsmRaw
Hands full with Taiwan / party congress
https://theprint.in/defence/india-and-china-air-forces-hold-maiden-talks-in-ladakh-as-lac-tension-escalates-to-sky/1070592/
1 leathel confrontation since Xi is in power. So the baserate is about 6-7%.

Lowering my forecast due to the passage of time. Also, it appears Taiwan is the more pressing area where Xi will want to apply military pressure. I would think that would mean he wants other fronts to be calm.
Talks continue between China and India to resolve a standoff in Ladakh. Once the cold weather sets in chances diminish for confrontation.

If China wants to pile pressure on to Taiwan, it's extremely likely to avoid a border conflict with India. There is still the possibility that India could use an active China-Taiwan conflict as an opportunity, but I don't think we will see an actual war between China and Taiwan just yet (hopefully...).

Could only see one incident in past two years that has caused casualties, so a 5% chance over two years. With only 5 months left this should give a 1% but I've left it at 3% given only one casualty is needed for a Yes.

In my forecast on the previous edition of this question I had it at roughly 2% per month, which I think was close to accurate. However since that question we've gone another 9 months without conflict, so I'm reducing my rate slightly.

Anchoring to @Kogo 's rationale, given little military conflict expertise of my own. I am adjusting down the base rate to 1/10 per year (4.6% for remaining 5.5 months of the year) as I view the probability of such lethal conflict as remote, particularly given more recent news of a 16th round of meetings between the two sides signaling progress.

Commander-level conversations are continuing, but no resolution (https://www.tribuneindia.com/news/nation/16th-round-of-india-china-lac-talks-end-in-stalemate-413559). As long as they keep talking, it's a good sign.

Seems unlikely; since Galwan there have been many rounds of talks. Unless something changes very drastically (e.g. the Dalai Lama visited Leh two days ago), there won't be direct conflict. China's attention is focused on COVID-19, the upcoming CCP meeting, and potentially Taiwan.

This is a hard one to gauge because of how little we know about what would set it off. I'd argue the most likely way for this to come about will be due to a rise if tensions between individuals at the border, not any decision making from higher up. I'm leaving my guess (relatively) high because I haven't seen anything that says those tensions will have substantially declined. I'd say it will happen again in the next 5 years, so I'll leave it just under 1/5th.
calibrating

It is unlikely because both sides will engage in saber-rattling and India will use it to galvanise nationalistic fervour amongst the ruling party's base. India knows that the cost of direct confrontation is too high and none of the western powers will come to its aid. Moreover, India realises that USA will want some kind of military engagement with China so that it can fight a proxy war

Based on the rationale of @incertum and considering the question fro @Kogo, I am going to lower my forecast slightly; however, I am going to keep it above the crowd given the tail risks and range of outcomes that could cause one fatality, which would resolve the questions to Yes - 100%.
Unlikely for China to escalate before NPC. India also has little incentive to escalate since the domestic election is still far away.
China and India appear to becoming closer economic allies given the sanctions on Russia
China has showed no signs of easing tension in the area disputed.
It's been two years since the last such altercation.
I believe the probability is very low for three reasons:

There are 120,000 troops. Assuming an average company size of 6-12, you get 10-20k groups of people that can independently choose violence. Between a tenth and a twentieth of those will get the relevant chance, so roughly 1k companies of 6-12 with guns, all quite tense.

While Xi Jingping has been more aggressive in asserting its view of Chinese borders and sovereignty, a sanctioned military offensive is highly unlikely given China's ongoing COVID recovery. But given that backdrop, military officials and personnel are morel likely than usual to act aggressively.
not confident at this time, will continue to update.

A clash requires one side to send troops onto the glacier, a deliberate action authorised from the political leadership. There are no routine patrols because the environment is so inhospitable. Then the other side will surely respond by sending troops, at which point a direct clash is maybe a 10% chance.
Indian armed forces on the border received upgraded weapons. Increase in discipline and scrutiny. Outweighs national pride.
Dialogue seems to preferred course of action atm, though there are military buildups in the region.

China and India have engaged in 5 border skirmishes in the past 780 days (10 May 2020, 15 June 2020, 19 October 2020, 9 January 2021 and 20 January 2021). Out of these 5 incidents only one (15 June 2020) resulted in fatalities (20%).

I think it's a low probability. China got what it wanted out of the previous confrontation, which was to distract India into shifting resources toward its army, at the opportunity cost of not putting those resources in its navy. It's happy to have India continue draining its resources up in the mountains. From the Indian side, it doesn't gain anything from further clashes, so I would expect everything to remain quiet from their side as well.

Starting low, while there is still tension in the area it seems like it is not increasing for now with little motivation on either side to reverse this trend. There is still time for tensions to rise again of course and the possibility of an "accident".
